wikipedia_page.main: Margaret Elizabeth Jenkins  (31 October 1905 – 5 September 2010) was an English novelist and biographer of Jane Austen, Henry Fielding, Lady Caroline Lamb, Joseph Lister and Elizabeth I.

response: *Elizabeth Jenkins (En, 1905–2010) – Jane Austen, Henry Fielding, Lady Caroline Lamb Joseph Lister and Elizabeth I

This all came to an end in 1875 and 1877, with the notorious Penge murders. In 1875 Frederick Hunt murdered his wife and children,The Penge Murder, H. Sutherland, British Medical Journal v2 (766) 4 September 1875, 316–317 then in 1877 a wealthy heiress, Harriet Staunton, together with her infant son, was starved to death by her husband and his associates.The Great Penge Murder, Victorian Calendar 19 September 1877 http://victoriancalendar.blogspot.com.au/2011/09/september-19-1877-great-penge-murder.html In 1934, Elizabeth Jenkins published the novel Harriet, based on the case, whilst Forbes Road was renamed to Mosslea Road because of its connection with the murders.

* Elizabeth Jenkins (judge) (born 1950), United States federal magistrate judge

Writing in The Guardian, Elizabeth Jenkins called Welch's "capacity for description... astounding, [his] angle of vision unusual... his felicity inexhaustible... The book is a unique achievement."Jenkins, Elizabeth, The Guardian, 31 March 1950 An unnamed reviewer in Punch called it "[t]he best of his books... with the curious vitality of a minor classic."Punch, 22 March 1950 The editor of Readers News, the newsletter of the Readers Union bookclub, exhorted members to read the book, the work of "a promising talent, even perhaps genius... with extra care."Readers News, Vol 14, No 5, November 1951 Writing in The Daily Herald, John Betjeman was less equivocal. He simply entitled his review "Here's a work of genius."Betjeman, John, The Daily Herald, 8 March 1950
In 1934 Elizabeth Jenkins published the novel Harriet based on the case, supporting the view of the presiding judge, Hawkins.
